Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned a LOT of organic chemistry reactions, and learned how to use these reactions to produce complex compounds.
nope

I learned many things during the course of this class. They include 1) advanced organic reactions, 2) how to deal with a passive aggressive professor, 3) how to best guess the answers to homework problems that we were never taught
A "toolkit" of organic chemistry reactions that greatly enhance your ability to know how to create complicated molecules (if you can remember all of said toolkit and how to apply it).
I learned many reactions and mechanisms and learned how they all work together.
Reagents necessary for a reaction, how to think about multiple reactions for making a reactant into a product

I learned about the chemistry of aromatic and carbonyl compounds, as well as the chemistry of amines. I also learned how to use retrosynthesis to create plausible paths to make a given compound and how to propose new mechanisms based on existing chemistry.
Learned specific ways to formulate a reaction and deduce starting reactants by looking at product.
I furthered my knowledge of organic chemistry.
complex mechanisms, how to think about concepts behind mechanisms and not just memorize them
I learned over a hundred different reactions in organic chemistry.
I learned about organic chemistry. I learned how to study really hard.
I gained greater knowledge into a variety of organic reactions.
A great amount of synthesis of compounds

I learned so many organic reactions and their mechanisms. I also learned how to solve puzzles by doing organic retrosynthesis. By the end of this course, my study guides for each exam felt like a giant cookbook. Organic chemistry is so applicable to daily life, and this class really emphasized that.
About 150 reactions, all kinds of new chemistry, how to get through a very hard class
This course taught me a love for organic chemistry.
Problem-solving skills.
organic chemistry

In CHEM 221, you learn many reactions (by many, I mean SO MANY LIKE A LOT ALMOST TOO MANY). That's basically it: you just learn a lot of reactions, their reagents, products formed, the stereochemistry and regioselectivity involved, and the mechanism of a lot of them. Be careful, because there are a lot of reactions, many of them similar but give different products and regioselectivity.
I learned a litany of organic chemistry reactions involving specific functional groups and how they can be incorporated into broader synthesis strategies.
Learned conceptual aspects of organic chem as well as tons of reactions.
I guess I learned some Organic Chemistry reactions.

Learned about a variety of different reactions in organic chemistry, and why they proceed they way they do. This course also taught me how to study better, as the large amount of material to memorize requires dedicated studying.

I gained very little knowledge through this course and I''m not quite sure if it was my own lack of good studying habits or because the class jus tmoved too fast for my studying to keep up with among other things.
Understanding the puzzle that is organic chemistry from a synthetic approach. Finding new ways to mix together reactions to create a desired product.

Learned 3/4 of the organic chemistry textbook in this stick rearrangement class, and how to think creatively about making molecules. I now understand how to anticipate the product of a reaction based on conceptual understanding of molecular properties and reaction conditions rather than just rote memorization
Mechanisms of biochemistry
Learned more about the chemistry of different functional groups: alkynes, carboxylic acids, other carbonyl groups, etc.
I learned several more important organic chemistry reactions.
Organic chemistry
I learned a lot more organic chemistry. While first semester was a lot more based on the basic concepts of orgo, orgo 2 is much more about applications

I gained an extensive knowledge of organic chemistry that built on the basic principles established in the first semester of organic chemistry, as well as general problem solving skills and work with memorizing and organizing very large amount of information.
I learned about organic chemistry reactions and mechanisms.
it was a cool problem solving techniques for chemistry
I learned a lot about organic chemistry and different reactions and the underlying mechanisms of different reactions work.
I learned the intricacies of organic chemistry functional groups and their reactions.
A detailed understanding of organic chemistry, specifically the synthesis of chemicals.
I learned the chemistry behind many reactions of many different functional groups, as well as how to integrate their reactions in complex and meaningful ways.
Aside from furthering my knowledge on organic chemistry, I learned how to manage my time for this course and how to study throughout the semester.
I learned many organic chemistry reactions and some helpful organic chemistry concepts.
I learned about organic chemistry and how to synthesize many compounds.
This course taught me effective time management and course work organization.
I learned a lot about the details behind organic chemistry mechanisms and also the conceptual knowledge behind reactions.
You learn about more in depth reaction schemes and learn about retrosyntheses.
We learned how to think critically about reactions and synthesis of complicated molecules
How to study for an extremely hard class.

Students learn an absurd amount of organic chemistry. This class covers a breadth of reactions, mechanisms, and concepts about different classes of compounds. I think above all else, students learn to intuit what reaction may happen under different conditions, depending on the reagents, as well as evaluate what reagents are necessary to achieve a desired end product.
It's hard to say...there is just so much information that you just remember what you can and hope that you don't fail the tests.

I learned how to most effectively organize my class material to study for these exams which required an intensive amount of memorization. I'm very proud of myself for being able to get through this class. It has definitely got to be the hardest class I've taken so far at Yale.
Expanded on my organic chemistry knowledge.
In depth understanding and memorization of organic reactions and their mechanisms

How to propose a mechanism based on trends, such as how acidity levels affect proton transfers. Understanding what reagents are used for rather than just memorizing which ones are necessary for a reaction.

In this course, I gained the ability to apply the basics I learned from first semester organic chemistry into more complex mechanisms and synthesis questions. I learned how to problem solve and break problems down into smaller steps.

This class taught me to actually understand what organic chemistry is and why it is so useful and applicable. Yes you learn how to push electrons around by drawing arrows, but this class attempts to teach why we care about these reactions, and I think it somewhat successfully accomplishes that goal.

This course used a similar format to Orgo I, and largely the same vocabulary, but required learning a much larger volume of reactions. The focus is a bit more on synthesis/retrosynthesis to challenge the class to apply a lot of the reactions we learn. The content primarily covers the reactions of several key functional groups.
Lots and lots and lots of orgo reactions.
More organic chemistry. Nothing more, nothing less.

I gained nothing from this course except stress, anxiety, and self doubt. This is by far the worst course ever created. I am pre-med, therefore I have no interest in it, and will never use it again in my life. Two weeks after finishing the course, I cannot tell you one thing that I learned this semester because basically every reaction was memorized for the test and then forgotten.

This class was insanely rushed. The course covered many reactions as well as general principles of reactivity. It was a strange mixture of trivia, like knowing pka values for a given chemical on exams, memorization of probably hundreds of reactions and reagents (at least that's about how many flash cards I had ), and conceptual understanding of syntheses sometimes involving reactions we didn't really discuss.  This class seemed to really only be doable for those who had seen the material before in some capacity.

I learned a wide variety of reactions using plenty of different types of substrates and catalysts. I also learned to use general knowledge about chemistry and various reaction pathways to predict the mechanisms of new reactions. It seemed like a great introduction to me.
Too much material to cover effectively in the time allowed

Strengths: Having discussion section was a helpful way to get more instruction on confusing topics and also the practice exams were helpful to get a sense of what might be tested. Professor Schepartz is very engaging and enthusiastic.
Weaknesses: Professor Schepartz is very impressive but also slightly intimidating to approach and ask questions. We learned a lot of material in a very short amount of time, so keeping up with the material was difficult. Sapling was sometimes useful, but other times a lot of time spent on either really easy reactions or things we wouldn't need to know later for exams.

The weakness is that for much of the course, information is presented simply as memorization.  Not all material that you are expected to know is taught in class, and the exams are not at all reflective of the course material.  There are also five exams in total (including the final).

Here lie all of my Orgo 2 grievances!
Why was there a midterm on the last day of class? WHY WAS THERE A MIDTERM ON THE LAST DAY OF CLASS??????? Is this a joke to you? There are other classes besides yours! I know you think you're the center of the universe but you're not!
Also maybe get a less passive aggressive professor! She was SO rude any time anyone would ask a question or point out a mistake. 
Also don't lie to us and say we don't need to know nomenclature or NMR or IR and PROCEED TO MAKE HALF THE PSET FREAKING NMR!!!!!!!
Reactions and mechanisms make sense in class and are pretty interesting, but having to memorize them all, including the reagents and so on, was a bit overwhelming at times.

Where to begin. This class is absolutely awful. It could not be more perfectly designed for students to bomb. Organic chemistry is all about doing practice problems and noticing trends. So what do we do? Receive 2 worksheets of problems the entire semester and other than that are left with Sapling to learn everything as if the level of difficulty on Sapling is within even a 100 times the level of difficulty of the exams. Professor Schepartz doesnt even cover all of the material on her tests in lecture, sometimes you have to learn material that is going to be tested on from practice tests two days before your exam. If youre taking this class, its because you have to and all I will say is good luck. If you have Professor Schepartz you are screwed. We went so fast through the material that apparently we went two chapters further than last years Orgo II class. Probably why the averages on the last two exams were a 65 and 61. For the fourth midterm exam not only did we have just one worksheet of practice problems, the practice exams she uploaded were mostly on material 4 whole chapters beyond what we learned. So going into the last exam we had about 5 example exam questions to base our studying off of. The result? A 61 class average on the exam. This class is terribly organized and is designed for you to fail. The exams are also egregiously too long for 50 minutes. In Orgo I, we got 1 hour to take exams that were considerably shorter than the exams in this class. Anyone who did well in this class is simply a natural at orgo who needed very little instruction to do well. You know the kinds of kids Im talking about, the ones who get a 99 on an exam with a 61 average (some kid actually did that). I got an A in Orgo I and Lord knows what Ill be getting in this class. If youre just a normal student who is grinding through it avoid Schepartzs class at all costs. If you have no choice, buckle up.

I thought the material, while difficult, was taught very nicely. I didn't think that Sapling questions were always very helpful and were sometimes irrelevant. I did think that section and the practice question sessions in class were very helpful.

Strengths: the content, the support available by the TAs and Peer tutors, the lectures
It could be improved by being taught a little slower (like after midterm 3).

Strengths: It's really cool chemistry! You learn an incredible amount of stuff in just a few weeks. Also, Schepartz is a good teacher in that she knows her material and how to explain it really well and is in a pretty good mood for 9:30 am. She also is always willing to answer questions and adjust the pace of the class to match what students need (e.g. just cut out two chapters at the end of the course because she wanted to go over some other material in greater detail). There also isn't much homework, just some Sapling every unit. 

Weaknesses: Schepartz goes super fast in lecture, which can be hard to follow. It's a lot of material to learn, and you end up having to memorize at least some of it, like the reactants and reaction conditions. There's also not a lot of review material beyond just doing practice problems from the book.

The course pace was extremely fast, with a single cumulative midterm containing up to 30 new reactions. There could have been much more practice on retrosynthesis and homework questions tailoring to practicing that aspect. Sapling homework was not an effective way to practice concepts learned in class because it didn't teach you how exactly to think about certain reactions. Additionally, the course could be more organized in terms of presenting concepts. For instance, consolidating all reactions that involved creating a carboxylic acid, etc.
This course is easily the hardest thing I have ever done, which is why I dropped.  It is taught at such a fast pace that nearly everyone cannot hold on, and everyone always seems confused and lost.

It was definitely really fast (even though I know Prof Schepartz slowed down). But I appreciated that she tailored the pace to our needs a little bit at the end. I also hated the Sapling--it often didn't line up with the material we learned in class, so I felt like I was wasting my time with a lot of the questions (I googled so many answers). And it was super specific about grading, and didn't always have the same criteria for resonance forms that we learned in class. It was pretty useless and frustrating (and we had to pay over $40 for it)
This course has a lot of content to teach, which is always difficult in a large lecture course.

This course was pretty well taught and organized but for most of the semester it felt like we were just going too quickly. It was hard to keep up with all of the information. Also, having four midterms and a final exam was very overwhelming. The last midterm was on the last day of classes and then we had another exam a week later. This class might be more manageable if there were just four non-cumulative midterms.
This course is very difficult and it would be improved by teaching a smaller amount of material in a manner that makes it easier to understand.

The course was well organized, albeit I felt that practice exams could have been perhaps better tailored to the material actually covered on exams, as well as we would have appreciated if they were released earlier and not so close to the test dates. I also would argue that having 4 exams is unnecessary, as it felt that the final was just repetition on what was previously covered. Having just three exams allows for a focus on the final on the end of the material.
Homework not great

This course was extremely rushed and not very organized. The amount of material covered in one semester was disproportionate and very overwhelming for the students. Having 4 exams and a final was extremely exhausting and overwhelming, as well. This was by far my most stressful course at Yale.

The strength of this course is the material. Organic chemistry is always elegant and beautiful and is a pleasure to learn about. However, I wish that we got to cover carbohydrates and amino acids. I think one weakness of this course is that it didn't really feel like organic chemistry of *life processes*. The organic chemistry that we learned was very isolated from biology, and I would have liked to see more connection with the life processes because there was almost no connection with life/biology. In addition, we did not get to cover carbohydrates and amino acids, which was sad, because I was really looking forward to it! Sometimes the expectations for each exam were not clear as in we never know what we need to know for each exam, and it just feels like we have to know everything. The exams were admittedly pretty straightforward and easy, but often times the questions and reagents are not consistent with what was taught in class. For example we learned that LDA gives the kinetic enolate and NaOH in protic solvent gives the thermodynamic enolate, but some reagent questions wanted LDA even though the product was formed through the thermodynamic enolate. Another example is that one test question gave protic and basic conditions for an aldol condensation, but the answer key wrote that it was supposed to be the condensed product, however we learned in class and through the textbook that in basic conditions you can stop at the aldol addition product whereas in acidic conditions it goes straight to the condensation product. In addition, it feels like you are flying through 30 reactions every day, but I personally think it's worth it. To reiterate, I think it would be really valuable to cover carbohydrates and amino acids. I feel like I'm missing out on some major organic chemistry knowledge, especially because these macromolecules are so applicable to life. One strength of this course was the extremely rapid turnaround time for feedback on exams. One weakness is that the FOURTH practice exams were not useful to practice at ALL. One of the exams only had two problems that were applicable to what we learned.

Strengths: Prof. Schepartz is very nice, you get to drop a midterm

Weaknesses: Course moves WAY too fast, there is not really any problem solving done before the actual exam (we don't have psets or textbook problems), and Sapling is completely terrible. It does not help you learn any of the content whatsoever (if anything it makes it even more confusing because they sometimes use different reagents/conditions) and tests information not covered in class/exams (nomenclature, NMR). Some of the problems are incrediblely confusing and you may find yourself doing the same 12 step problem 43 times just to find that your original answer was correct but you missed a single lone pair. Overall, it's extremely frustrating and an utter waste of time (and $44!!). I would strongly recommend eliminating Sapling altogether and just assigning textbook problems.

I think it would be helpful to have shorter Sapling assignments, but on a weekly basis to match material learned in class. This would be much more helpful with solidifying knowledge and keeping students on track. I also think having a Piazza for the class would be really helpful, as I'm sure many students had similar questions and would benefit from peer/TA/professor responses to questions. Having four midterms and a final was pretty rough  I would have preferred three midterms and and final that emphasized concepts learned in the last unit.
No weaknesses.

Orgo 2 is a lot of work, but ultimately very rewarding. I definitely feel like I have a much better understanding of chemistry after this semester. The actual workload of the class in terms of graded work is minimal, but it takes a lot of time to fully learn all the reactions, especially before exams.
The lecture was difficult to follow and practice tests were not always relevant to what we were learning. Sappling questions not all helpful and relevant but take a lot of time.

This class moves through material very quickly. The material on exams does not reflect the material covered in class. Questions were not encouraged in class, because they slow down the class and the professor worried that we would not get through all the material. It's evident that the professor does not truly care how much we learn about the material. Strengths? --None in particular
way too fast. WAY too fast. you need to go slow and reemphasize CONCEPTS, not just reactions.

First off, weaknesses: the sheer amount of reactions you have to memorize, understand, and reproduce; the lack of guidance for studying for finals and midterms (just practice exams, no Loudon problems assigned); the heavy reliance on Sapling Learning even though it does not provide good practice for exams.
Strengths: the amount of time the peer tutors and teaching fellows put into review session and discussion sections

One that is both a weakness and a strength is that the class follows the textbook very closely, so during reading week, I just went through the textbook and studied the reactions from there, not even from my notes.

One weakness that I will not delve into here is how poorly run the STEM departments are at Yale: there is too much to say

Strengths: overall pretty engaging, interesting to me but some found boring, grading is consistent, defintiely challenges you 

Weaknesses: sometimes got a bit dry with lots of reactions, 4 midterms and a final is a lot, very time consuming

Frankly not too many strengths. The homework doesn't prepare you for exams, and some of it was completely unrelated to what we learned. The lectures went too fast, and it was hard to retain information. There wasn't too much real world application, so it just felt like drawing structures for the heck of it. The teaching was subpar, as well.

While the course cover interesting and manageable content, it was mismanaged and made into an overwhelming and stress-inducing endeavor for students. We were not given adequate preparation for assessments, as practice exams often covered content that we were never taught. Weekly problem sets (not sapling, but written out) that give us exposure to the type of questions that will be on exams would be very helpful. Additionally, Sapling problem sets were not tailored to cover just the material we were expected to know (they included irrelevant content).
The pace of the class was good, the material not too challenging, only there was a lot of it. There is more homework than in Orgo 1, but it helps you practice and learn the material.

A weakness was how little emphasis was put on specific important reactions and mechanisms to know.  I wish we didn't focus on concepts especially when we were barely tested on any concepts. I wish there was a clear list of reactions and mechanisms needed to be known on Canvas that we could study off of, rather than have to guess which reactions to study from the textbook. We also strayed from the schedule posted which made it a bit diffucult to understand which portions of the textbook we were still responsible for.
This class sucked. The tests were way too hard, the professor didn't know how to teach, and it made my semester miserable.

The professor is brilliant, but teaches at a pace faster than most of the students could handle. Also, provided practice exams often contained non relevant material  for the fourth midterm, 2 were provided but the entirety of the second practice exam was irrelevant. The 4 midterm schedule is rough, but perhaps necessary due to the sheer volume of content.
TAs are very inaccessible, the class was incredibly fast and hard to keep up with the material

Strengths: Well-taught by amazing professor, good practice with Sapling homework sets (without a lot of pressure to get them right the first try); accessibility of office and peer tutor hours
Weaknesses: very face paced (almost rushed) nature of course, especially with beginning half.

Strength: this course is rigorous and doesn't mess around. There's a lot of material to learn.

Weaknesses: Connections to life processes were not stressed. Lecture organization was hard to follow because she didn't reference which part of the textbook she was referring to. Tests were brutal and required you to memorize things like the exact pka of a type of hydrogen, which isn't useful and made studying even more difficult than it already was.
So much info
The professor does not have a good sense of the students' interests or reasons for taking the course. It is chaotically run and focused much more on memorization than understanding.

The course teaches a lot of material very quickly, which is in some ways both a strength and a weakness. It is great to learn so much, but can be overwhelming and requires spending a massive amount of time outside of class to stay on top of the material, which can be extremely stressful when a student is taking other difficult classes. The exams were particularly stressful because they covered, in detail, material that was rushed through in class. Further, there was not much personal feedback, as the class is taught as such a large lecture and the only graded work are exams and online homework. The responsibility falls almost entirely on the student to constantly fill in the blanks from class using the textbook and online resources, and to figure out how to study. Finally, I found it very frustrating that new material was often rushed through in the class directly before an exam, and that the midterm practice exams often did not align with what we had actually learned, further making it difficult to study and know what to focus on.
It has too much material and it went by too quickly. More practice problems and structured sections would have been helpful.
teacher weak

Sapling shouldn't be used for this course because it's honestly useless and many of the questions are irrelevant to the course and overly specific, and it just takes time away from studying the material in a helpful manner. However, it would've been helpful to have specific textbook problems recommended or assigned because many of the concepts we went over were difficult to understand without practice, and we weren't given that practice. Additionally, we were clearly expected to think a certain way about chemicals and reactions in this course, but lectures weren't framed this way and it was really hard to learn the deeper concepts and ideas when they were only mentioned once in passing and not written down. This made the course almost totally memorization, which it really shouldn't be if there's deeper understanding. Also, I understand that we have to get through certain material, but the course was really fast paced. Also, although the practice tests were helpful, it would be helpful to have more practice tests or practice tests that accurately reflect what's on the exam, since the practice tests weren't indicative of what we had been learning, and left us unprepared for the real tests. However, the discussion sections were helpful, and my TA (Aarushi Gupta) was incredibly helpful and without her I wouldn't have understood many of the complicated ideas in class. She explained things well and clearly, and her practice problems were really useful.
Select TAs very involved and knowledgeable.
The course has to cover a large amount of material in a short period of time. It would benefit from having a more organized atmosphere.
I wish that more (optional) study questions had been suggested from the textbook.

Strengths: The material is fascinating, and the problem-solving aspect of this course is unlike any other. It requires a lot of memorization, as well as a high-level of perceptiveness and critical thinking. Prof. Schepartz is clearly an expert at her field, and she is a good instructor. 

Weaknesses: The practice tests could be updated to reflect the actual level of difficulty of the exams.

This course is very fast-paced and the homework is long and tedious. However, the problem sets are not intensely difficult in content and there is unlimited attempts at each question, which is very beneficial.

This course was taught at a very quick pace and the material we were expected to know mainly composed reaction reagents and mechanisms, with relatively few concepts. Emphasizing the chemical concepts would have been much more useful for preparing for the future and taking away a greater understanding of orgo rather than memorizing reactants that were quickly forgotten.
I thought the tests were unreasonably with the specificity and how quickly no credit was given for partially correct answers.

The course is very difficult and time and energy demanding. The effectiveness of section depends on the TA you are assigned to, but overall is good to facilitate student learning. Lack of adequate explanations for practice test answers should really be addressed. It would really help students understand the material more easily.
The course can be more organized with more support in the form of enrichment classes or optional problem solving sessions to prepare for exams.
The course presents a lot of material which is really good for learning but also makes the course extremely difficult.
The strengths were the sections and the TAs helped a lot, but I believe sapling isn't the best place to facilitate learning of this type of material.

The subject is really difficult, but the course is well structured and organized. The sapling problem set questions were not always relevant to what we had done in lecture, which was at times frustrating, but overall, the class was very formative.
Written problem sets should be assigned.
The class was well structured and the content was engaging. It was a little bit fast paced, but manageable to stay on top of.

The material in this class is quite interesting!

However, it is presented in such a convoluted way and at breakneck pace - there is virtually no way to remember and truly internalize all of the reactions we learn. I really feel that the class sacrifices quality of learning for the quantity of information that students are expected to be responsible for. I think the teaching style can be greatly improved.
It's well-organized, but somehow the instructors thought that was enough justification for its breakneck pace. Students are rarely able to catch up.

There was A LOT of material, to the point of making me overwhelmed when studying for midterms, crammed into one semester. This was a stark difference in comparison to CHEM 220, so if there was any way some of the material from 221 could be shifted over to 220, this might help the issue. While majority of the material was new, there was quite a lot that drew on things from 220, which I felt was a bit unfair because these things were not reviewed whatsoever but merely expected of us to remember. The four midterms in one semester also ramped up the workload quite a bit, but I guess having the last midterm so close to the final date helped me study for the final.

The class was taught extremely fast and with sub-par teaching fellows or resources to refer to, it was very hard to keep up with. It is clear Professor Schepartz is very knowledgeable, but the class itself was just not taught well.

Very fast paced
Need to keep up with the material every week to do well
4 exams and it is possible to drop one, which is nice, but also means you have an exam every 3 weeks, which is demanding and requires a lot of time and organization

Strengths: All of the practice exams are extremely helpful in solidifying your knowledge. Professor Schepartz follows along with the book pretty well, and the Sapling is helpful with its practice problems.

Weaknesses: Sapling is sometimes repetitive and contains questions that are not helpful to the course, such as naming organic compounds. The book goes into more detail than is needed at times.

I think that this course moved very quickly, so it would have been nice to slow down or have more frequent review sessions to make the information easier to grapple with. Additionally, I would have loved to have problem sets more closely mirroring test questions rather than Sapling homework assignments.

Change the professors. Make it a smaller lecture -- maybe have two sections of it? Or get rid of one of the lecture days in order to have an additional discussion section. It is an impossible amount of information and in order to go through it all the professors did not stop to take many questions or really explain what was going on. If they really can't cut back on the amount of reactions we need to go through, they need to incorporate more extra learning time, because it is impossible to understand what is going on the first time you see it, and discussion sections early in the week do not cover a whole week's material, only one lecture's worth. I would say over 50% of this material was never actually taught to me.

Weaknesses was the Sapling homework that honestly was often a waste of time and asked for mechanisms that we did not even learn. I also did not think having practice exams and keys for them posted literally one or two days before midterms to be effective, especially because these are just old exams. It seems silly to make TF's write answer keys for these too--why isn't there already answer keys written since these were old exams?

Generally, the lectures were clear and well-organized, and followed the order in the book fairly closely which made it easier to follow. Although exams were very difficult, the expectations were clearly delineated beforehand regarding what kinds of problems there were. The primary weakness was that the lectures were extremely fast-paced; we ended up not covering a lot of content at the end of the course. I wished that could have been decided ahead of time so we could have gone more slowly all along rather than only slowing down at the end. Often we were scrambling to take down the notes without having the time to understand the material during lecture. Also, it was often unclear for which reactions we were responsible for the entire mechanism vs the scheme vs aspects of the mechanism, etc - compared to Orgo I, it was much harder to predict what would be emphasized on exams. Also, discussion section was extremely disorganized / not worth attending and seemed highly variable based on what TA you had - having standardized practice problems or review topics would have been much more helpful than a generic Q and A format when often students hadn't yet studied enough to formulate questions.
This class moves very quickly. If you fall behind, it's difficult to catch back up. It's a LOT of work. I can't stress this enough.
Sapling questions were sometimes very different from what we learned in class.

The course by nature has a lot of material and is very difficult in terms of studying for exams. Unfortunately, this class was particularly poorly organised to facilitate even minimal retention of the information. This was not helped by lectures moving way too fast, and us being told we would not be allowed to ask questions.

Needs consistent answer keys and grading
Should be better taught 
Sapling questions were not helpful on exam but I didnt like the sapling system better than psets
Maybe have saplings due weekly with harder more exam-like questions

There really is no improving this course because organic chemistry in itself is terrible. Maybe if the professors took more time to teach a chapter rather than cramming us with too much information every week, we would do better on the exams. They're so focused on getting through a certain amount of chapters that they literally speed through everything.
I thought that the peer tutors were helpful. The course itself was very fast paced and I wished the sapling questions weren't due 2 days before the midterms, rather one due each week.

The class had the potential to be really great but it was taught so poorly. If the lecture notes had been more concise or more practice materials given out and gone over, maybe it would have been doable but as it was the class only brought stress, anxiety, and lots of crying.  There wasn't very much structure to the material. It was mostly just going to lecture three times a week to write down as quickly as possible what was put on the board and especially what was said, as much of what was said was not written down but definitely important to understanding the material. These notes were virtually useless, at least to me, as I could not find any way of helpfully organizing the material in my head despite trying different methods for each exam.The TAs could also be helpful to this extent as hopefully some of them also had similar struggles that they learned to overcome. It is not useful to have only experts teach students because experts do not remember what it was like to not understand the material. This is why I think Dr Martinez was not helpful in section. The sapling problem sets began as being very easy and maybe somewhat related but after the first 2 assignments the questions were tedious and definitely not representative of what we learned or what was on the exams.

I thought it was perfectly fine for the most part. The one thing I would suggest is a change in the sorts of problems assigned on Sapling. Problems which require us to draw mechanisms take an excruciatingly long time (10-15 minutes at least per mechanism that I could easily write by hand in 1 minute) because Sapling's platform is very slow. Sometimes my browser would crash as well. For reference, I am not using an old computer or anything. I would often have to skip completing these problems altogether simply because I had better ways to spend my time studying to do well in the course. However, the synthesis questions in sapling which gave starting materials/products and required us to draw/select reagents were very good and helpful. Since mechanisms come down mostly to memorization, I think it would be great if possible to have fewer mechanism problems on sapling and more synthesis problems.
Sapling is not good practice. We should have better practice and it should be every week, not before a test.
Only if you need it for pre-med
I wouldn't recommend this course to anyone who doesn't have to take it, as the amount of memorization required for each test consumes a tremendous amount of time and the material is painfully boring.

Yes. I think Orgo II is a useful class and was also fun to learn for me. It is, however, a LOT of material, and therefore critical to stay on top of the material. It can be difficult to stay on top of the material, since we don't really have weekly psets to keep up with the reactions. If you try to do Sapling or read parts of the textbook early, then that might be useful.
No.  Do not take if not required.
HA! Is that a joke?

If you take this class, you'll come out knowing a lot more about ways you can manipulate reactions, and you learn a lot more reactions than in orgo 1. That being said, there's a good chance you'll feel over-saturated with molecules and reactions and reagents and mechanisms at some point during the course. There are a lot.
If youre taking it, its because you have to. So whether I recommend it or not youre gonna take it and let me just tell you its the worst class of all time.
I would recommend this course if they are interested in learning about organic chemistry reactions.
Yes! I highly suggest it to students who like chemistry and like problem solving.

Yeah! It's a really good complement to Orgo I and gives a good idea of how you can predict the chemistry and reactivity of compounds through their structure. It's tough but a good time if you're into it. That said, it's definitely focused on organic synthesis in the lab and not so much how organic chemistry pops up in other places like biochemistry or industry, so if you're not a chem major or pre-med, its focus might seem a little narrow.
NO.  NEVER. This is the worst class I have ever taken and would encourage students to NOT take it.  It is way too hard and unless you have time to solely focus on this one class, you won't do well.
Don't take it unless you're ready to work hard.
I would not recommend this class to people who don't need it as a requirement as it is a huge time commitment.
Only if you need it for credit.
This class is a good elective for the MCDB major, but I would not necessarily recommend this course to someone looking for a SC credit.
Only take it if you have to.
You are probably taking this because you have to, but you really do learn a lot if you put the effort in.
Only if its for your major or you have a ton of extra time
No.

I would recommend this course to another student because organic chemistry is elegant and applicable to real life. Even if it is not required for pre-med I would still take it. Just make sure you have time to devote to this class. Take it with a maximum of one other hard STEM class, and you should be good. It's not as bad as people make it out to be. I think it is a very fulfilling class.
I would not take it unless you have to (premeds: you really do not have to take this class! run while you can)
Yes.
Yes, I would. It's a lot of work, but you'll get a lot out of it if you put in the time.
Not unless they have to. Very difficult and will take away from engagement in other courses.
No. Avoid this class at all costs if possible. Your brain will go numb with visions of hexagonal benzene rings haunting your dreams. This class will crush your intellectual curiosity.
really only if you have to take orgo 2.
I would recommend this course only if you either: 1) need this course for your major, or 2) you ABSOLUTELY cannot stand the fact that you will miss taking organic chemistry at Yale.

The truth is that many of my peers and I took this course because it is part of a mandated requirement outside of the chemistry major, namely as a medical school prerequisite. That being said, I cannot earnestly recommend this course to a student who does not need to take it. I have an enjoyable experience with most chemistry courses at Yale because they showed me how their content related to real world problems, like drug manufacturing or creating durable materials. Here, the course makes little effort to explain how any of the hundreds of reactions covered in the semester are applicable. If this is something that deeply interests you as someone interested in the chemistry major, then perhaps you might be enjoy the rote memorization which will expand your toolset for organic synthesis going forward.

Not really. If you don't need to take it, probably best to spare yourself the work. But if you do or are considering it, it's fine. Just know that the tests are quite difficult and conceptually challenging. The workload is actually pretty low if you just do the Saplings, but you need to put in a lot of time studying on your own to do well. Schepartz can seem a bit mean at first but is honestly really funny and a pretty decent lecturer once you get used to her breakneck pace.
Only take it if you have to. But if you have to, it is managable if you really stay on top of everything. If you get behind - it is over.
Nope, unless you have to take it for pre-med or your major, which is the reason most people are in the class. It frankly is just not well taught and uninspiring.
Not unless you have to.
If you have to take it...

No, not really, unless another instructor taught it and you needed it for medical school. Just be prepared to memorize lots of reactions and keep track of which ones you need as the book has a few extra reactions and the class also adds additional reactions not in the textbook.
No. This was absolutely horrible. Would not wish it on my worst enemy.
Dont.

Youre probably taking this class because you have to, so the most I can say is that it isnt as bad as other comments may make it seem  but only if you review your notes and keep up with studying and practice problems. Do not cram!!!
Only if you absolutely need to
I would recommend to anyone who willingly wants to learn about organic chemistry, or who has to for premedical requirements.
Yes if its a premed or chem requirement. No otherwise.
Its required for pre med
Definitely a huge commitment, midterms were a lot to study for
Take this course if you must. It won't help anything except your transcript.
I would recommend this course to students who are interested or need it as a prerequisite, but warn them to be ready to dedicate vast amounts of time and effort to studying for it.
You should only take this if you are a pre-med or a chemistry major. Otherwise, don't.
nope only if you need it
No, because the material is not overly interesting and it was a hard course. However, most people take this course because they have to so it doesn't really matter.
Do not take this unless you have to.
Generally if you are taking this class, you absolutely need it. It is a lot of work, but is certainly interesting at times.
If you're up for a challenge. Definitely not if you're doing this for fun.
I would only recommend this course to another student if they have to take it for their major or pre-med.
If this class is required by your medical schools then take it but otherwise take biochemistry instead or Credit/D this class, as I wish that I had.
If you need it. Its fine.
I'd recommend the course but would advise other students to be ready to do a lot of studying on their own. Lectures tend to be unorganized
Take this course if it is required, or if you have a deep interest in chemistry. It is interesting if you enjoy visualization and problem solving.
I would only take this course if you have an interest in Chemistry or have to take it for pre-med or a major.
I would only recommend this course if it's a requirement.
Chances are you need to take this course. If Professor Schepartz is teaching it, it won't be that bad. She is, though intimidating at first, very reasonable and rational.
Take it if you must, but it will consume a lot of your time. It will be extremely rewarding if you put the work in!

I think that this class is a prerequisite for many students, so there is not a lot of choice involved. However, I would recommend this class to other students for the content alone, accompanied by the warning that this course will likely consume their entire schedules. Approaching test dates, I (along with many of my peers) drop everything to study for the class - extracurriculars, sleep, other classes, meal times (and even not during testing weeks). The course is all-consuming - in large part because of the instruction (convoluted, fast, inconsistent across lectures, opaque) and not the innate nature of the material.
If you are pre-med thinking about this class, get ready for a lot of work. Otherwise you probably have to take this class like I do.
if you're up for a challenge, yes
Not particularly. Take the first semester of Organic Chem because Professor Elman was terrific, but if you don't have to take this one, save yourself a lot of stress.

Yes, if you like chemistry and biology, you will like this course.
However, it is very different from General Chemistry, so do not base your decision on that.

Given that this course is usually only taken because students have to take it (Chemistry majors, pre-med), it's not so much a question of recommendation as it is a question of how this course is going to be. It's a challenging course, especially if you are going down the straight memorization route. Take the time to understand why things happen and what each reagent is used for, and you will have a much easier time. Highly recommend looking at a book named "Chemistry as a Second Language" and going through every single practice exam available.
I would recommend this course to students who are interested in organic chemistry, willing to work hard, and ready for a challenge.

If you're taking this course, it's probably cause you have to for your major or for med school. This class was really hard. Having a midterm every three weeks really requires you to have your stuff together. Review daily and memorize those mechanisms. Conceptually, it's the same level of difficulty as Organic Chemistry I, which that's a small plus. But midterms heavily test on understanding mechanisms, so definitely prioritize on learning those.

As it is currently designed, no. It is mainly memorization, and there are simply too many reactions to be reasonable to learn. Although Alanna Schepartz explained things better than Jonathan Elman did in orgo 1 and it seemed like orgo 2 would be more focused on the big picture, it really is just memorizing equations and arrow drawing. This is one of the most painful classes I have ever taken. Plus, we had 4 midterms (one on the last day of classes) plus a cumulative final.

Most students who take this course are taking it because they have to, so this question isn't entirely applicable. I am premed and many medical schools do not require Orgo II anymore. Some premeds seem to have aptitude for organic chemistry and don't find it particularly difficult. I'm a humanities major, I struggle with orgo more than most do, and probably could have saved myself a lot of stress and disheartening grades by not taking the class at all. Unless you're the kind of person who is intellectually fulfilled by memorizing to a deep enough level that you can figure out just about any kind of question, I would avoid it if you can. For reference, the first midterm requires learning approximately as many reactions as the first semester of organic. If you do have to take it, do not take it in a 5.5 credit schedule; if orgo is challenging for you conceptually, it requires a few hours of studying after every lecture to feel comfortable with the material (a level I never quite achieved). Anecdotally, it seems that in the past it has been poorly taught but graded much more leniently, whereas this is the reverse experience. It isn't an unfair course at all, and my opinions are probably clouded by my frustration with the material -but do proceed with caution.
Please only take this class if you absolutely have to.  A midterm every couple of weeks is rough.
Not unless you need it. This class made me stop being a chemistry major.
No, badly taught, did not feel like I leaned any new conceptual chemistry, just a bunch of memorization

I would never recommend this course to another student. I only took it to fill a pre-med requirement. Now I understand why so many people over time decided to not become doctors  they had to take organic chemistry.
Only if you have to take it
If you could find a way to not take this course by all means. Usually it is a requirement so doesn't really matter what I say.
There isn't much reason to take the course if you aren't going into a related field, and if you are going into a related field, it's required.
If you have to take it.
